q: What are the signs that a child may have problems with their vision?
a: Signs that a child may have vision problems include narrowing or squinting their eyes, covering one eye with their hand, turning their head in unusual ways, and looking sideways instead of facing forward.

q: What should I do if I think I or my child might have double vision?
a: If you think you or your child might have double vision, you should go to an optician or see a GP for a sight test to get it checked.

q: What happens at a double vision appointment?
a: At a double vision appointment, an optician or GP will ask about your symptoms and perform some simple, painless eye tests. They may refer you to an eye specialist for further tests and treatment if needed.

q: What should I do if I have eye pain and double vision?
a: If you have eye pain and double vision, it is recommended to ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111.

q: What are the possible treatments for double vision?
a: The best treatment for double vision depends on the underlying cause. It may include simple treatments such as eye exercises, wearing an eye patch, or being prescribed glasses or contact lenses. In some cases, eye surgery may be necessary.

q: How can I determine the cause of my double vision?
a: You can try covering one eye at a time to see if the double vision goes away. If it persists in the uncovered eye, it is likely only affecting that eye. Double vision affecting both eyes is usually a symptom of a squint.

q: What are the common causes of double vision?
a: Double vision can be caused by various factors. Double vision affecting both eyes is usually a result of a squint, where eye muscles or nerves cause the eyes to look in slightly different directions. On the other hand, double vision affecting one eye is often caused by eye problems such as dry eyes, astigmatism, cataracts, or keratoconus.

q: What should I do if I'm diagnosed with double vision?
a: If you're diagnosed with double vision, it is important to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) as it may affect your ability to drive.

q: How can I inform the DVLA about my double vision diagnosis?
a: You can find out how to inform the DVLA about your double vision diagnosis by visiting their website.

a: Signs that a child may have problems with their vision include narrowing or squinting their eyes to try to see better, covering one eye with their hand, turning their head in unusual ways, and looking at you sideways instead of facing forward.

a: During an appointment for double vision, an optician or GP will ask about your symptoms and perform some simple, painless eye tests. They may refer you to an eye specialist in the hospital for further tests and treatment if necessary.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for double vision?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if you have eye pain and double vision, or if you have a severe headache with blurred or double vision. You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

q: How is double vision treated?
a: The eyecare team or GP can advise you on the best treatment for double vision based on the cause. Treatment options may include eye exercises, wearing an eye patch, being prescribed glasses or contact lenses, or in some cases, eye surgery.

q: What are the possible causes of double vision?
a: Double vision can have many possible causes, depending on whether one eye or both eyes are affected. Some common causes include squints, dry eyes, astigmatism, cataracts, and keratoconus.

q: What should I do if I'm diagnosed with double vision?
a: If you're diagnosed with double vision, it's important to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) as it may affect your ability to drive. You can find out how to inform the DVLA about double vision (diplopia).

q: How can I determine if my double vision is monocular or binocular?
i: Try covering one eye at a time to see if your double vision goes away. If you still have double vision in the eye that is not covered, it's probably only affecting that eye.
a: You can determine if your double vision is monocular or binocular by covering one eye at a time. If the double vision goes away when one eye is covered, it's likely affecting only that eye. If the double vision persists in the uncovered eye, it's affecting both eyes.

q: Are squints more common in children?
a: Yes, squints are more common in children. However, they do not always cause double vision. An untreated squint in children under 7 can cause a lazy eye instead.

q: What eye problems can cause double vision in one eye?
a: Eye problems such as dry eyes, astigmatism, cataracts, and keratoconus can cause double vision in one eye.

q: What are the signs that a child may have problems with their vision?
a: Signs that your child may have problems with their vision include:narrowing or squinting their eyes to try to see better, covering 1 eye with their hand, turning their head in unusual ways (for example, tilting their head), looking at you sideways instead of facing forward.

q: How is double vision treated?
a: Your eyecare team or GP will advise you on the best treatment for double vision based on its underlying cause. Treatment options may include eye exercises, wearing an eye patch, or being prescribed glasses or contact lenses. In some cases, eye surgery may be required.

q: What are the possible causes of double vision in one eye?
i: If you still have double vision in the eye that is not covered, it's probably only affecting that eye.
a: Double vision affecting one eye (monocular) can be caused by eye problems such as dry eyes, astigmatism, cataracts, or keratoconus.

q: What are the possible causes of double vision in both eyes?
i: Try covering one eye at a time to see if your double vision goes away.
a: Double vision affecting both eyes (binocular) is usually a symptom of a squint, where problems with the eye muscles or nerves cause the eyes to look in slightly different directions.

q: Are squints more common in children or adults?
a: Squints are more common in children, but they do not always cause double vision. An untreated squint in children under 7 can lead to a lazy eye. Squints in adults can sometimes be a sign of a more serious condition.

q: When should I inform the DVLA about my double vision?
a: You must inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) if you're diagnosed with double vision as it could affect your ability to drive.

a: You can find information on how to tell the DVLA about your double vision (diplopia) on their official website.
